name: Potato Casserole
description: Make those potatoes go the extra mile with this cheesy potato casserole! Fit to serve a crowd, this casserole is the ultimate comfort food.
recipeIngredient: 3 1/2 cups extra sharp cheddar cheese, divided ($3.21)

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat the oven to 375Â°F. Peel and dice the potatoes, finely chop the onion, and mince the garlic.
recipeInstructions.name: Preheat

recipeInstructions.text: Add the potatoes to a large pot of water. Bring to a boil, cooking for 8-10 minutes until fork tender. Strain in a colander. Then, transfer the potatoes to a greased 9x13 casserole dish.
recipeInstructions.name: Boil

recipeInstructions.text: While the potatoes are boiling, melt the butter in a large saucepan or pot over medium heat.
recipeInstructions.name: Melt

recipeInstructions.text: Add in the onion and salt, and cook for a few minutes until softened. Add in the garlic and cook for a minute. Then, stir in the flour.
recipeInstructions.name: Cook

recipeInstructions.text: Slowly pour in the milk while whisking to incorporate.
recipeInstructions.name: Pour

recipeInstructions.text: Add in 2 cups of cheese and the sour cream. Stir until melted and incorporated.
recipeInstructions.name: Stir

recipeInstructions.text: Pour the cheese sauce over the potatoes. Gently combine until the potatoes are fully coated.
recipeInstructions.name: Combine

recipeInstructions.text: Top with the crushed cereal and the remaining 1 1/2 cups of cheddar cheese.
recipeInstructions.name: Top

recipeInstructions.text: Bake for 20 minutes until the cheese is bubbly.
recipeInstructions.name: Bake

review.reviewBody: For us, it was too much onion. Some people enjoy a strong onion flavor and that's fine! But if you're not a huge fan, I would suggest trying 1/4 onion instead of 1/2. You can always freeze the unused portion to use later, so nothing goes to waste.
First time trying this recipe and myself and my family were thrilled by the taste. It's truly the ultimate comfort food.
What else is there besides fresh cubed potatoes? I figured it was the only thing to use. Lol jk. Being sarcastic my friend.
You could also try crushing up some potato chips for the topping.  By doing so you can reduce the salt to perhaps 1/2 tsp or eliminate it all together.
Yummy, goey yet crunchy all in the same moorish mouthful.

Love that this recipe uses fresh potatoes. Crushed corn flakes were a common casserole topping when I was growing up--a real taste from my childhood! I made a half recipe in a 8" baking dish, and we barely had enough leftovers for a 2nd meal.
